Comment: I accept
bien
Puzzle is now ready for playing. The PL/0 language is a simple but powerful language which has been used for years to teach compilation technics in universities.
Description, code and cases updated following all comments.
Whew. Really Complex... looks good though.

in EBNF definition, there is a ; in program after "." 
is it possibly a typing error?

Just a quick glance - I see that some [[variable]] formatting should be changed to {{constant}} formatting, and vice versa, in all the sections. Would you please fix all of them?

A few examples:

Goal
* #, ! and ? - {{constants}}

* N - [[variable]]

Input
* COMMAND - [[variable]]

* COMPILE, PROCESS - {{constants}}

Thanks.
Done, I was mixing both notations.

Well, this is a copy/past from Wikipedia where this appears to separate some lines of EBNF. But you are right, especially with Pascal like syntax it can be misleading. All real symbols are in fact placed between quotes. So, let's remove it. Thanks for spotting it.
Thanks for your approval. Unfortunately, one missing for getting fully approved. Don't hesitate to reapprove ;-)
Thanks for your approval. Unfortunately, one missing for get fully approved. Don't hesitate to reapprove ;-)
Many thanks for your support.
Thanks a lot for your approval.
The missing . and extra ; have been fixed. Thanks for pointing out the comments.

Thank you.

I suppose it's fine even if the dots aren't added, since that's not the primary error to catch in the code. Still, it wouldn't hurt to include them anyway.

By the way, will you be replying on the forum?
Agreed and I added them. It is better to respect the grammar.

Fair enough.
Are you going to reply on the forum?
yes just did it. yesterday was a crazy day ! Thx.
No worries!

It looks like one semicolon still slipped through. See the forum message here: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-simple-pascal-pl-0-compiler-puzzle-discussion/204437/16 . The issue has now been fixed.

I need your help to reapprove this puzzle.

Many thanks in advance.

I need your help to reapprove this puzzle. Just one approval missing and 1 day left.
Thanks in advance.

Goal
* EBNF definition: Sometimes a space follows an opening bracket ( [, { or ( ) and sometimes it does not. Please be consistent.

* EBNF definition: Sometimes a space precedes a closing bracket ( ], } or ) ) and sometimes it does not. Please be consistent.

* Please mention what [[ident]] is for (variable name?).

* Line N: Please format "N" as a [[variable]].

* Please add explanation on how source code should be converted to PL/0 instructions.

* Please change "1 for neg" to "1 argument for neg" for clarity.

* Please add a line break between one instruction and the next for clarity.

* Please change "1 for odd" to "1 argument for odd" for clarity.

* Please mention that for math and comparison operations involving 2 arguments, the argument popped first is the first operand and the argument popped next is the second operand (if that is the case).

* jmp: Please explain how position is defined.

* jpc: I don't understand the explanation. What comparison (>, <, >=, <=, #?) should be performed? Should I perform comparison when I see "jpc"? But you mention "previous" comparisonâ€¦ It's confusing.

* Please change "is defining" to "defines".

* Please change "so level 1" to "i.e. level 1".

* Explanation inserted between the instructions is confusing (i.e. between jpc and cal, between cal and int, between int and lod) and interrupts the logical flow. If possible, please move all such explanation to somewhere before the "8 instructions" section.

* Following the previous point, you mention "the processor pushes 3 values onto the stack" between cal and int, and then what "the 3 pushed values are" is explained below sto. If possible, please group them together.

* In the same paragraph:

   â€¢ It seems that {{call}} should be changed to {{cal}}.

   â€¢ What do you mean by "same when starting the program"? Do you mean "When a procedure is called by {{cal}} [[l]]{{,}}[[a]] or by starting the program"? If so, please rewrite that way.

   â€¢ What do you mean by "[[b/l]]"? [[b]] divided by [[l]]? Also, "/" should not be applied the [[varible]] format.

   â€¢ Suggest to change "then" to "The values of the registers change too:" for clarity.

* Please change "this one" to "it".

* Please change "relative position" to "relative address" (or vice versa) for consistency.

* lod: Does "difference of levels l" refer to the relative address instead of the stack? If so, please move "onto the stack" to the end.

* Please remove all the unnecessary line breaks (see https://imgur.com/a/KYmRYFr ).

Input
* PROCESS: Please fix the typo: "langage" => "language".

* Line 2: Please add "An integer" in front of "[[N]]".

* Line 2: Please delete "on the next lines".

* Please change "N lines of" to "<<Next [[N]] lines:>> Integers for the".

* Please change "Line N+2:" to "Next line:".

* Please change "{{M}}" to "An integer [[M]]".

* Please change "M lines of" to "<<Next [[M]] lines:>> Strings for the".

(comment reached word limit, to be continuedâ€¦)

Output
* Please format "," (between "level" and "argument") as a {{constant}}.

Constraints
* Please include the lower limit of M.

Cases
* I'll review it later.

Thanks.

Thanks for your detailed review. Looking at your questions, it seems clear that more details need to be provided to help users to succeed in the implementation. So, I am thinking to split this into two different puzzles, one for the compiler to produce instructions, and another one to process instructions. I will update this in the coming days.
Sounds good; it does seem there may be too much material for a single puzzle.
Here is the new first part.

Thank you. Revised comments as follows:

Goal

* Paragraph 1: Please change "PL0/" to "PL/0".

* EBNF definition: Sometimes a space follows an opening bracket ( [, { or ( ) and sometimes it does not. Please be consistent.

* EBNF definition: Sometimes a space precedes a closing bracket ( ], } or ) ) and sometimes it does not. Please be consistent.

* Error message: Please change "<<Line [[N]] message>>" to "{{Line }}[[N]]{{: }}[[message]]".

* Error message: Please format "element" as a [[variable]].

* The PL/0 instructions: Please change "proceeding line by line" to "from the given program".

* The PL/0 instructions: Please change "are relaying" to "rely".

* Nesting level: Please change "is defining" to "defines".

* Nesting level: Please change "defined into" to "defined in".

* Nesting level: Please change "level 1 and so on" to "i.e. level 1, and a procedure block defined in a level 1 procedure is level 2, and so on".

* Nesting level: Please change "this one" to "which", and delete the comma before it.

* Nesting level: Please change "relative position" to "relative address" for consistency with the later text.

* 8 instructions: Please change "the the" to "the".

* 8 instructions: Please change "number of nesting levels difference" to "difference in nesting levels".

* 8 instructions: Suggest to add an example and/or a simple pair of cases for the calculation of [[l]].

* lit 0, a: Please change "push" to "pushes".

* opr 0, a:

  â€¢ Please change "execute" to "executes".

  â€¢ Please change "0: this" to "{{0}}: this".

  â€¢ Please change "is done" to "is performed".

  â€¢ Please change "1 for odd" to "1 argument for odd" for clarity.

  â€¢ Please mention that for math and comparison operations involving 2 arguments, the argument popped first is the first operand and the argument popped next is the second operand (if that is the case).

  â€¢ Please change "13 pop" to "13 pops".
  
  â€¢ Please change "it 14" to "it, 14".
  
  â€¢ Please change "14 get" to "14 gets", and then "push it" to "pushes it onto the stack".

* jmp 0, a:

  â€¢ Please change "jump" to "jumps".

  â€¢ Please explain how position is defined: (a) does it refer to the program or the instructions? (b) does it refer to the **line** position? (c) does position start from 0 or 1?

* jpc 0, a:

  â€¢Â Please change "pops" to "pop".

  â€¢Â Please change "looks" to "look".
  
* cal l, a:

  â€¢ Please change "call" to "calls".
  
  â€¢ If definition of [[a]] is the same as that in "jmp" (as per comment above), then please change "= instruction position" to "see {{jmp}} for the definition of [[a]]" after you have added the explanation to jmp.

* int 0, a: Please change "allocate" to "allocates".

* lod l, a: Do you mean lod pushes a variable onto the stack and store it at relative address [[a]]? Also, what variable are you referring to? Do you mean duplicate the value at the top of the stack?

(to be continuedâ€¦)

* sto l, a:

  â€¢ Please change "store" to "stores".
  
  â€¢ "pops value": Do you mean "pops value from the stack"? Is this essentially moving a value from one position on the stack to another position on the stack?

* Some hints for generating instructions: Given that only general hints are available, are you sure each program corresponds to a unique set of PL/0 instructions? Is it possible that there is more than one possible answer for a test case?

* Some hints for generating instructions > condition: Please change "principle than" to "principle as".

* Some hints for generating instructions: The example is incomplete. Please complete it and/or use a simpler complete example.

Input
* Please change "of of" to "of".

Constraints
* Please change "source" to "program" for consistency.

Cases
* I'll review them later.

Thanks.

Thanks again for your review. I agree that some elements could be clarified but it is challenging as I reached the max number of characters... 

  â€¢ Please explain how position is defined: (a) does it refer to the program or the instructions? (b) does it refer to the **line** position? (c) does position start from 0 or 1?
It refers to instruction position starting from 0.

Do you mean lod pushes a variable onto the stack and store it at relative address [[a]]? Also, what variable are you referring to? Do you mean duplicate the value at the top of the stack?

Yes, the variable content is somewhere into the stack. Lod gets this value (at relative address [[a]]) and duplicates it to pushed it on the top of the stack.

Is this essentially moving a value from one position on the stack to another position on the stack?

Absolutely.

* Some hints for generating instructions: Given that only general hints are available, are you sure each program corresponds to a unique set of PL/0 instructions? Is it possible that there is more than one possible answer for a test case?

Generally speaking there is never a single solution when talking about programming and I wonder the same question when I started to work on this puzzle. The PL/0 language is limited and the number of instructions very small. Of course, you can always be creative and produce something different. However, from a logical standpoint, there is a direct mapping between a PL/0 command and PL/0 instructions. which should drive the vast majority of players to reach the same results.

Thank you again for your reply and follow-up. Revised comments as follows:

(If you cannot fit some of the text in the statement, I would suggest to simplify other parts of the statement.)

Goal
* Please add the heading <<Error messages>>.

* Error messages: Please add "{{: }}" between [[N]]" and "[[message]]".

* Error messages: Please change "Errors" to "Error".

* Error messages: Please format "element" as a [[variable]].

* Nesting level: Please change "is defining" to "defines".

* Nesting level: Please change "defined into" to "defined in".

* Nesting level: Please change "level 1 and so on" to "i.e. level 1, and a procedure block defined in a level 1 procedure is level 2, and so on".

* 8 instructions: Please change "number of nesting levels difference" to "difference in nesting levels".

* 8 instructions: Suggest to add an example and/or a simple pair of cases for the calculation of [[l]].

* 8 instructions: Please delete the ":" in the heading.

* opr 0, a: Please mention that for math and comparison operations involving 2 arguments, the argument popped first is the first operand and the argument popped next is the second operand (if that is the case).

* jmp 0, a:

  â€¢ Please change "jump" to "jumps".

  â€¢ Please change "in the code (next instruction to execute)" to "(instructions are indexed line by line starting from 0)".

* jpc 0, a:Â Please change "pops" and "looks" to "pop" and "look" respectively.
  
* cal l, a: If definition of [[a]] is the same as that in "jmp" (as per comment above), then please change "= instruction position" to "see {{jmp}} for the definition of [[a]]" after you have added the explanation to jmp.

* lod l, a: Please change "variable" to "value".

* sto l, a: Please delete "in variable".

* Some hints for generating instructions: The explanation to the example is incomplete. Please complete it and/or use a simpler example.

Input
* Please delete the first sentence.

Output
* Please change "Print the" to "The".

* Please add "of the given program" after "(one per line)".

Constraints
* Please change "<=" to "<".

Cases
* I'll review them later, and also I'll have to think about the issue of unique solution.

Thanks.

Additional comments:

Goal
* Paragraph 1: Please fix the typo: "exectue" => "execute".

* Paragraph 1: Please change "Niklaus Wirth is" to "He is".

* Please add the heading <<Error messages>>.

* Nesting level: Please add "." after "and so on".

* jmp 0, a: Please delete "in the code".

* int 0, a: Suggest to rewrite as follows as there is no explantion of what [[a]] is:

{{int 0,}} [[a]] allocates space onto the stack. [[a]] refers to the number of spaces. Each time a block is called, 3 values are pushed onto the stack (see above), so [[a]] is equal to 3 plus 1 for each variable.

* Some hints for generating instructions:

   â€¢Â Please format "expr" as a [[variable]] or in <<bold>> instead of as a constant (twice).
   
   â€¢Â Please format "condition" as a [[variable]] or in <<bold>> instead of as a constant.

Expected output
* Any reasons for jmp to appear before int when the main program starts execution? Conceptually speaking, shouldn't stack space be allocated before doing anything else?

Thanks.

I tried to accomodate last updates with remaining space.

Expected output
* Any reasons for jmp to appear before int when the main program starts execution? Conceptually speaking, shouldn't stack space be allocated before doing anything else?

Everything is possible :-).

jmp is transferring the execution to the first instruction of the main block twhich does not involve any stack action. stack allocation happens when entering a block.

"Everything is possible" just goes contrary to what a CG ordinary puzzle should be ðŸ˜‰ If multiple answers can be correct for a test case, the author must tell the player how to choose the one to match the author's expected output. The CG puzzle engine is unable to accept any other answers as correct.

Well yes of course.
However, I think the description of the rules/instructions give enough guidance to match the solutions. For this precise case, two elements:
- The instructions are generated following the program order.
- int 0, a -> ... Each time a block is called ...

But you also say "Each time a block is called (including the main block)". I assume that just **starting** the program calls a block, right? And that's especially true for those programs without any jmp instruction. How would the coder know why jmp should be put first if there's a jmp?

The jmp instruction is only used if there are procedures. Why this ?Because the instructions of procedure are appearing before the main block (following the program order).
Proceeding with the jmp first allows to keep the exact same approach for all blocks where int is needed.

Thank you for your explanation but I still don't quite get it ðŸ˜…. I think you'll better understand my view after reading the latter half of the revised comments below.

Revised comments:

Input
* Next N lines: Please add "Some lines may begin with spaces or tabs."

Constraints
* Suggest to add a constraint which states that in this puzzle, all math and comparison operations work from left to right (e.g. there won't be cases like 2 + 7 * 9).

(Note: I don't know how operator precedence works in PL/0. I assume multiplications and divisions should be done before additions and subtractions?)

Goal
* Please change "memories" to "memory".

* PL/0 Grammar - !: Please change "print" to "prints".

* PL/0 Grammar - ?: Please change "get" to "gets".

* "[[numbers]] are only integers": Should "integers" be changed to "non-negative integers"?

* Please add the heading <<Error messages>>.

* Please add "and [[message]] is one of the following:" after "line number of the error", and then delete "Error messages are".

* Please delete "The PL/0 instructions
PL/0 is composed of 8 instructions which rely on a stack structure to push and pop values."

* Nesting level: Please add "." after "and so on".

* Can constants be allocated onto the stack? If not, please mention that (because that's one of the differences betweeen my PL/0 codes and yours; more on that below.)

* Please add "Every block has its own stack, which is used to push and pop values." in front of "Each time a block is called".

* Please add "at the relative addresses (index) of {{0}} to {{2}}" after "the PL/0 processor".

* Please add "starting at the relative address of {{3}}" after "for each variable".

* Please delete "To access a variable, we use its position in the stack minus 1. If we have 1 variable which is at the 4th position on the stack, the relative address is 3."

* Please change "<<8 instructions>>" to "<<PL/0 instructions>>".

* Please add "8 instructions are available in PL/0." in front of "In the following instructions".

* Please change "l is the difference" to "l is the absolute difference".

* "a is an integer argument": Please change "an integer" to "a non-negative integer".

* opr 0, a: Please mention {{/}} is floor division (result is rounded down).

* jmp 0, a: Please delete "in the code".

* jpc 0 a: Please add "to instruction at [[a]]" after "then jump".

* Please add "[[l]] levels above" after [[a]] for
  â€¢ cal l, a
  â€¢ lod l, a
  â€¢ sto l, a

(to be continued in my next comment)

(â€¦continued)

Cases
I've tried to solve all the cases and most of my PL/0 codes are different from yours. Hence the following questions:

* As mentioned earlier, one difference is caused by the question of whether constants can be pushed onto the stack.

* The "Odd and Neg" pair of cases is simple and should be moved to earlier (it's better to order the cases in ascending order of difficulty).

* "Odd and Neg" test: It seems more meaningful to print j than to print i at the end.

* "Odd and Neg" pair of cases: My code are different from yours. The reason seems to be that your Part II code answer is wrong:

elif param == PL_OP_ODD: self.stack[t_reg-1] = 1 if self.stack[t_reg-1] % 2 else 0

should be:

elif param == PL_OP_ODD: self.stack[t_reg-1] = 0 if self.stack[t_reg-1] % 2 else 1

* The "No BEGIN" pair of cases is simpler for learning how nesting works and I would suggest it be swapped with the "Procedure" pair of cases.

* For all the other differences between my PL/0 codes and yours, would you please review them and see if my codes are in any way inconsistent with the puzzle statement? If yes, please point them out; if not, please resolve the issue of "no unique solutions".

My codes: https://pastebin.com/geSXcxNj
(link will expire after 2 weeks)

Some of the possible solutions are:
* Add new rules to the statement (but frankly, this solution may still fail because there are so many possibilities when writing a code).

* Re-create the puzzle using CG's SDK. That enables the possibility of using a referee to judge the player's answers, and multiple answers can be accepted.

Thanks.
Would you please change the status back to WIP? Your puzzle is a complex one, and it shouldn't be published for approval so soon.
Sorry, for whatever reason I did not see all your last comments.

Noted.

Also, in case you missed my comment I made earlier today on your other puzzle:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/79182d49d41a4512a966f68695f00f0c9b811

* Suggest to add a constraint which states that in this puzzle, all math and comparison operations work from left to right (e.g. there won't be cases like 2 + 7 * 9).

Yep, good point.

(Note: I don't know how operator precedence works in PL/0. I assume multiplications and divisions should be done before additions and subtractions?)

Indeed.

* Can constants be allocated onto the stack? If not, please mention that (because that's one of the differences betweeen my PL/0 codes and yours; more on that below.)

Definitely yes. Everything is based on the stack. This is the role of the "lit" command.

* The "Odd and Neg" pair of cases is simple and should be moved to earlier (it's better to order the cases in ascending order of difficulty).

Yep right. But very basic question, is there a way to exchange tests ordering ? 

I look at your code now.

For the first program, the difference is that you manage the constant as a variable.

Simple example Test
int 0, 5
lit 0, 5
sto 0, 3
lod 0, 3
sto 0, 4
lod 0, 4
opr 0, 13
opr 0, 0

The "int" pre-allocate spaces for the famous 3 values and variables only.

stack = [ v1 | v2 | v3 | var i ] so int 4

Thanks to this, it moves the stack pointer after those 4 values.

then to use the const value, just put it on the stack with lit 0, 5

stack = [ v1 | v2 | v3 | var i | 5 ]

So, no dedicated storage for constant. By changing this you should get the same code.

Looking to other differences, at least I see a problem in all programs where there is a constant.

Odd and Neg Test
int 0, 5
opr 0, 14
sto 0, 3
lod 0, 3
sto 0, 4
lod 0, 3
opr 0, 6
opr 0, 6
jpc 0, 12
lod 0, 3
opr 0, 1
sto 0, 4
lod 0, 3
opr 0, 13
opr 0, 0

In this one, the only difference is that you have twice the same line ( opr 0, 6 ) which seems an error. Same error in the validator.

With this, we should have now the same results I think.
Indeed I missed your updates and forum's inputs... :-(

No worries. I'll make sure you know ðŸ˜‰

Quick remarks:

1. No easy way to exchange order of cases. You'll have to cut and paste to swap cases around.

2. There are also differences in our codes related to (a) the ordering of instructions, and (b) your seemingly wrong code of the `odd` operation.

Also, I'm targeting to post my comments on Part II within a day or two.

Order of instructions: in the samples I looked at, we were having the same order. 

your seemingly wrong code of the `odd` operation: what do you mean ?

Thanks again for all your efforts and support. Much appreciated.

Please read the code I wrote slightly above the pastebin link for more details of the issue of the `odd` operation.

Order of instructions is different e.g. yours has jmp before int, but mine has int before jmp.

Have you seen my answer a bit above on 'odd' ? The only difference between our program is the line opr 0, 6 which appears twice on your side.

On the order, the only difference is indeed only on the first instructions as you do 'int' before 'jmp'. On my side, I put the main block after the jump, so doing the 'int' at that time. Technically both are working for sure, it is just a decision or convention to decide. This could be added as a constraint ?

I meant this:

elif param == PL_OP_ODD: self.stack[t_reg-1] = 1 if self.stack[t_reg-1] % 2 else 0

should be:

elif param == PL_OP_ODD: self.stack[t_reg-1] = 0 if self.stack[t_reg-1] % 2 else 1
Thanks for the debugging :-)
No problem. And that change in the processor means the PL/0 instructions have to change too.
Right ! Updates are coming and btw better understanding your double opr 0,6 :-)

* "[[numbers]] are only integers": Should "integers" be changed to "non-negative integers"?

Yep.

* Can constants be allocated onto the stack? If not, please mention that (because that's one of the differences between my PL/0 codes and yours; more on that below.)

No allocation but only push.

* Please add "Every block has its own stack, which is used to push and pop values." in front of "Each time a block is called".

Well, this is not exactly true. There is only one stack. Each block during execution has its own frame. This is more explained in the second part.

I still have a doubt on the ODD operator. I am looking at ETH source code in Pascal P4 which implements a PL0 compiler/processor. 

I used this input:

var i, j;

begin
    i := 5;
    j := 0;
    if odd i then
        j := 1;    
end.

And I got:

jmp  0    1
int  0    5
lit  0    5
sto  0    3
lit  0    0
sto  0    4
lod  0    3
opr  0    6
jpc  0   11
lit  0    1
sto  0    4
opr  0    0

So, they don't double opr 0, 6. I am trying to find a doc.

btw, even with no procedure, they put a "jmp". could be a solution to define a convention ?

That is why I'm so worried about cases having multiple possible solutions instead of a unique solution. So I keep saying that you have to mention everything in the statement to request the player to follow a specific way of solving the puzzle, if you don't use a SDK referee which allows any right solutions.

Sure, I understand. Never looked at the SDK, so could be indeed a solution. 

So no doc, but the original source code... and, there is something different and much more logical compared to the site I used as reference !!! and clearly this was buggy. Sorry for that.

First, very logical True is 1 and False is 0. So.... for jpc no need to generate the reverse condition, and so, no need to double opr 0, 6 for ODD. So, I update the description and the cases. 

Next step, clarify the 'jmp' position case which is I think the only open point.

Wow. That's a great improvement. It felt very weird and I first read that True = 0 and to implement jpc every condition need to be reversed. Discovering True = 1 is the way to go is excellent, good job!

What do you think to add the following description:

The first instruction of each block is a 'jmp' instruction to jump over all instructions coming from nested procedures (if any) up to a 'int' instruction to allocated needed space onto the stack for the block.

May be not fully english, but this would I think fix the only open point.

The logic behind my PL/0 codes having int before jmp is that I create a block as soon as I see "var"/"const" (which is also what the EBNF definition shows).

The logic behind your PL/0 codes seems to be that you create a block only when you see "begin" (or a simple statement without "begin"). That's why the instructions of any nested procedures always appear before the instructions of the main procedure.

What is the right way to do it? I think the puzzle statement may explain that instead of stating that "jmp" should always be the first instruction when there are nested procedures.

Doing some tests with original compiler, they always start a block with "jmp". This is clearly not optimal but at least it constraints things much better. 

So, I updated the description, completing the code and tests.
OK, maybe both ways are correct, but they've chosen that and we just follow them.

Yes I think both are correct and probably many others like reordering the main block to put it first :-)

So everything has been updated. Should be almost good now. I need to work on the part II to align everything.

A massive thank you for all your engagement and support.

You're welcome. Thank you for following up all along too!

I'll take a break now and get to the 8086 puzzles tomorrow or on Monday, and after that I'll get back to the PL/0 puzzles.

Goal
* I've removed some unnecessary trailing spaces, rearranged and rewritten some of the texts to add some new explanation and stay within the word limit. Would you please review the revised version at https://pastebin.com/TZdWatUp and if ok to you, replace the original version with it?

Cases
* Please change one of the no-error visible tests to have the program lines in UPPERCASE so that case-insensitivity is covered in a visible test.

* "While and If" test: Please add a statement which contains "#" so that "#" is covered in a visible test.

* "While and If validator": Please change "# 0" to "> 0" so that ">" is covered in a validator.

* "; missing" test: The error is in line 3 instead of line 4?

* "; missing validator": The error is in line 6 instead of line 8?

* "Missing symbol validator": The error is in line 4 instead of line 5?

Error line number
* The error message "Unknown variable" is missing from Goal section. That should be added.

* The example "proc sub;" you've quoted is irrelevant because no error message stated in Goal is applicable.

* I suggest the rule to be:
If the error is an unknown variable or an element already defined, then the line containing such variable or element is considered to contain the error. For other errors, the line containing the last valid token is considered to contain the error.

* If the above rule applies, in "; missing validator", the error is in line 6 (that's where the last valid token is) instead of line 7.

Scope
* I suggest the wording be revised as followsï¼š

[[ident]] is visible in the block where it is defined and all the <<nested>> blocks. [[ident]] can be overloaded with a new definition in a <<nested>> block, and it will be visible in the same way, without affecting [[ident]] in the <<nesting>> blocks.

Quick question first:
Only variables can be overloaded? Constants and procedures cannot?

If so, the following statement should be amended:
[[ident]] can be overloaded with a new definitionâ€¦

The question arises because
(a) In your revised case, var j is defined in the main block, but then const k is defined in the procedure within the main block.

(b) For the reverse case, if I define a const k in the main block, and then try to define a var k in a procedure, that'll give me an "unknown variable" error using your code (although that error seems to be wrong; it's more like "const already defined").

(c) And separately, there's also the "procedure already defined" error, but I don't know whether that applies for nested procedures (e.g. defining procedure named "a" inside a procedure named "a"), i.e. whether overloading procedures is acceptable.

After the clarifications, there'll definitely be more revisions in the casesâ€¦

Thanks.

Normally all idents scopes should work the same way independently of the element they represent (const/var/proc). So the rule stated in the goal is valid for all idents.

Now, may be there is a bug in the solution :-) I will have a look soon and I plan to update the "scope case/validator" to add more reuse of ident cross const/var/proc.
I updated scope case/validator with a mix of ident overloading. No bug found in the solution.

This is because a statement without using "begin" is limited to 1 element.
So on line 10: Unknown variable is the variable k.

?I; ?k;...

In "run", as there is no begin, only ?I; is considered inside run. ?k; is considered in the main block where k is not a variable.

I see! I was being an idiot ðŸ˜†

One open point:

A question to be consistent in error messages:
- When a token is missing we used its keyword, for example: "var already defined" or "procedure already defined"
- When a grammar element is invalid or missing, we used a descriptive message, for example: "Unkown variable" or "Invalid statement"

For expression, the grammar notation is indeed "expr", but I think it would be more consistent to output "Invalid expression" rather than "Invalid expr" as error message, wdyt ?

For the record: There are many possible error scenarios, and few of them are tested. Based on the error messages listed in the statement alone, it's difficult to know which scenarios a solution code should cover.

For example, the current "invalid statement" cases focus on one scenario only: assigning a value to a constant. I would imagine the same error message (or maybe "invalid expr"?) also applies to: "123 := i", "const i := 123", "const i = -123", "const 123 = i", "? 123", "if 123 then ? i", "if i = 7 then 123", "procedure 123", "begin 123; ? i", "run proc"â€¦

Having said all the above, I won't propose further changes in relation to this point. It's difficult to cover everything. An alternative is to remove all error casesâ€¦ but I dunno. I'd be interested to see others' opinions.

He is right !!!! In fact looking to my source code, I discover this comment for the parse statement is not in line with the documented grammar.

# "begin" statement { ";" statement } [ ";" ] "end"

Looking around for PL/0 examples,  you found all kinds of things with the most permissive one as the one I implemented. However, the original version (http://pascal.hansotten.com/niklaus-wirth/pl0/) is in line with the most restrictive version. 

So, either we amend the grammar to allow it or we change all examples to enforce the original grammar. My approach would be more for option (2) but is changing a bit the current puzzle for the one who did it.

wdyt ?

Based on that, I will answer and change.
